Straws

Straws are primarily recycled into their byproducts of polypropylene (#5). Polypropylene is used to make pallets, bottles, jars, yogurt containers, hot beverage cups, and food packaging. Also, heavily used in the automotive industry to make batteries, bumpers, instrument panels, interior elements, and door trims. Straws are NOT biodegradable in nature by themselves, but instead break down into smaller plastics, called microplastics, which cause further environmental pollution and health problems. Use paper straws when you can!

Read More

Single-Use Drinking/Juice Bottle

Recycling 1 ton of plastic bottles saves 7.4 cubic yards of space in landfill. Recycling 1 aluminum can is equivalent to 2.5 hours of TV with the energy saved. 2.5 million plastic bottles are thrown away every hour and it takes 450 years for each bottle to degrade by itself. Main recyling byproduct is polyethylene terephthalate (PET). PET from recycling is refactored into a lot of things, even like T-Shirts!

Read More

Squeezable Bottle

Squeezable Bottles, like sports, ketchup, mustard, and mayonnaise, are recycled into byproducts called low-density polyethylene (LDPE). LDPE from recycling is used to make products like bread wrappers, dry cleaning bags, shrink wrap, and grocery bags.

Read More

Deli Food Container (Clear)

Vast majority of food containers are made up of #1 plastics, which means when recycled are broken down into their byproducts of polyethylene terephthalate (PET). PET can be refactored into the makings of a variety of things like seat belts, bags, carpets, roofing insulation, and clothing. I bet you didn't know your clothes were made from plastic recycling!

Read More

Styrofoam Container

Styrofoam easily pollutes land and wind because of its lightweight nature allowing it to esily flow around. Wildlife even mistake styrofoam for food and ingest it. At its invention, Styrofoam was thought to be virtually safe for the environment, but researchers have found its degradation over time releases gases into the air called, chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs). CFCs have been linked to ozone layer degradation. Styrofoam's primary recycling byproduct is polystyrene (PS).

Read More

Yogurt Container

Yogurt Containers are mostly made up of #2 and #5 plastics which are high-density polyethylene and polypropylene, respectively. What you probably didn't know is that you need to clean your yogurt cups before recyclying! Recycling facilities have issues with contaminated yogurt cups and have to take them to landfills instead of recycling if they aren't cleaned!

Read More

Syrup Container

Syrup Containers are primarily composed of polypropylene. Polypropylene is a highly adaptable material that can be used for making clothing, industrial materials, and kitchenware. Similar to yogurt containers, make sure you clean your syrup containers! Leftover residue interferes with the melthing process and so instead they'll be taken to landfills

Read More

Butter/Margarine Container

Butter Containers are primarily made up of a mixture of plastics. The three major byproducts from recycling are polystyrene, polyvinyl chloride, and acrylic/nylon. Butter packaging is one of the most overlooked items when people think of recycling, but by doing our part we can prevent them from ending up in landfills perpetuating the problem. You can reuse your butter packaging for fun ideas like a mini herb garden!

Read More

Milk Jug

Milk gallons are primarily recycled into their byproduct of high-density polyethylene. 47% of US Citizens find their milk gallons are difficult to recycle. This is due to its large size when compared to a small plastic bottle. The EPA has found that fewer than three out of ten high-density polyethylene milk jugs are recycled in the US. Unfortunately, US consumers are skeptical the milk jugs are even recycled and so put them in the garbage bin instead.

Read More

Frozen Food Bags

Frozen food bags are primarily recycled into their byproducts of polypropylene, high-density polyethylene, and polyethylene terephthalate. Most people don't know they can recycle frozen food bags because they do not see the recycling symbol on them. This isn't the case for all so be on the lookout for the symbol to see recycyling eligibility. No symbol means there is an extra layer around the plastic meant to keep the food fresh.

Read More

Bread Bag

Bread bags are primarily recycled into their byproducts of polythene, polypropylene, and low-density polyethylene. Do not put your bread bags in your recycling bins because they can get tangled in the processing equipment causing damage and even injuries to the workers. You want to check your local grocery store to see if they can take it off your hands for recycling.

Read More

Grocery Food Container (Non-Clear)

Vast majority of food containers are made up of #1 plastics, which means when recycled are broken down into their byproducts of polyethylene terephthalate (PET). PET can be refactored into the makings of a variety of things like seat belts, bags, carpets, roofing insulation, and clothing. I bet you didn't know your clothes were made from plastic recycling!

Grocery Food Container (Clear)

Vast majority of food containers are made up of #1 plastics, which means when recycled are broken down into their byproducts of polyethylene terephthalate (PET). PET can be refactored into the makings of a variety of things like seat belts, bags, carpets, roofing insulation, and clothing. I bet you didn't know your clothes were made from plastic recycling!

Plastic Wrap

Plastic wraps are primarily recycled into their byproducts of polyvinylidene choride(PVC) and low-density polyethylene. Do not put plastic wrap in your local curbside bin for recycling. It could potentially damage the plants equipment and harm the workers. You want to take your plastic wrap to participating grocery stores and they'll take it off your hands to recycle.

Read More

Grocery Bag

Grocery bags are primarily recycled into their byproducts of high-density polyethylene and low-density polyethylene. Do not put your grocery bags in your recycling bins because they can get tangled in the processing equipment causing damage and even injuries to the workers. You want to check your local grocery store to see if they can take it off your hands for recycling.

Cleaning Container

Cleaning containers are primarily recycled into their byproducts of polyethylene terephthalate, high-density polyethylene, and polypropylene.

Read More

Chemical/Oil Container

Chemical/oil containers are primarily recycled into their byproducts of high-density polyethylene. You want to make sure your oil and chemical containers are completely cleaned and drip dried before placing into your recycling containers. Otherwise, contaminants can mess up the recycling process.

Read More

Soap Bottle

Soap bottles are primarily recycled into their byproducts of high-density polyethylene and low-desnity polyethylene. Soap bottles can't be recycled using your local curbside containers because it's made up of a mexiture of plastics. You want to take the emptied containers to local participating recycling plants that will recycle it.

Read More

Pipe

Plastic pipes, PVC Pipes, are primarily recycled into their byproducts of polyvinyl chloride. PVC pipes can't be recycled using your local curbside containers because it's made up of a mexiture of plastics. You want to take the emptied containers to local participating recycling plants that will recycle it.

Children/Pet Toys

Children/Pet Toys are primarily recycled into their byproducts of polyvinyl chloride.

Blister Pack

Blister Packs are primarily recycled into their byproducts of polyvinyl chloride and polypropylene.

Read More

Shower Curtains

Shower Curtains are primarily recycled into their byproducts of polyvinyl chloride. Polyvinyl chloride is used to make a variety of things like piping, blood bags and tubing, wires, insulation, and windshield systems.

Read More

Home Construction Materials

Home Construction Materials are primarily recycled into their byproducts of polyvinyl chloride. Polyvinyl chloride is used to make a variety of things like piping, blood bags and tubing, wires, insulation, and windshield systems.

Read More

Disposable Diaper

Disposable Diapers are primarily recycled into their byproducts of polyethylene, polyester, and polypropylene. Diapers have an interesting recycling process where they are heated up to 250 degress Celsius to get rid of all contaminants and pathogens first. Unfortunately, the majority of diapers don't even get recycled and end up in landfills because people don't bother.

Read More

Outdoor Carpet

Outdoor Carpets/Door Mats are primarily recycled into their byproducts of polypropylene.

House Wrap

House Wrap are primarily recycled into their byproducts of polyethylene.

Read More

Medicine Bottle

Medicine Bottle are primarily recycled into their byproducts of polypropylene and polyethylene. When you're done with your prescription bottles, you don't have to recycle them in your local community bin if you worry about your information getting out there. Your local pharmacy should have a drop off or a mail back program to help you recycle them.

Read More

Baby Bottle

Baby Bottle are primarily recycled into their byproducts of polypropylene. Before recycling your babies bottle, make sure they are empty, dry, and the cap is screwed on before placing in your bin.

Read More

CD Case

CD Case are primarily recycled into their byproducts of polystyrene and polypropylene. CD cases do not biodegrade easily and they contaminate the soil and air with toxins. It's best to recycle them so they do not end up in landfills.

Read More

Disc

Discs are primarily recycled into their byproducts of polystyrene. Discs are a little more finnicky to recycle compared to their case counterpart. Discs can be recycled throught the e-waste route. The majority of our global e-waste goes to Asia and Africa where they are melted down for their valuable parts.

Read More

Disposable Silverware

Disposable Silverware are primarily recycled into their byproducts of polystyrene and polypropylene. Plastic spoons and forks can be recycled, but you need to make sure you take them to a special recycling facility. This is due to their small and inconsistent sizes.

Read More

Insulation

Insulation are primarily recycled into their byproducts of polystyrene. Make sure to contact your local county council for specific recycling services for your insulation. This isn't like throwing a bottle in your blue bin, but rather a specific disposal site is needed.

Read More

Reusable Water Bottle

Reusable Water Bottle are primarily recycled into their byproducts of polypropylene and copolyester. Reusable water bottles are a step in the right direction opposed to using single use plastic bottles. Just don't forget to recycle it when you're done. You could also use it in a lot of fun ways like an ice pack or a vase, as long as you don't throw it away!

Read More

Lid

Lids are primarily recycled into their byproducts of polyethylene terephthalate and high-density polyethylene. Similar to thier plastic bottles counterpart, people usually only recycle the bottle, but don't forget about the lid too! Lids end up ruining habitats and animals end up eating them thinking they are food.

Read More

Electrical Part

Electrical Part are primarily recycled into their byproducts of polystyrene. Electrical parts are a little more finnicky to recycle because they are considered e-waste, but don't let that stop you! The majority of electral appliance retailers can take them off yours hands for recycling. The majority of our global e-waste goes to Asia and Africa where they are melted down for their valuable parts.

Read More

Other Container (Non-Clear)

Storage containers aren't the first thing people think of when it comes to recycling, but this bulky/large containers are made up of plastics that can degrade further into microplastics if dumped. These containers can be recycled to help manage their byproducts of polypropylene and polyethylene terephthalate (PET). Contact your local recycling facility for further information on how to recycle this object.

Read More

Other Plastic Bag

Other Plastic Bags are primarily recycled into their byproducts of high-density polyethylene and low-density polyethylene. Do not put your plastic bags in your recycling bins because they can get tangled in the processing equipment causing damage and even injuries to the workers. You want to check your local council for specific regulations and facilities to take it off your hands for recycling.
